Fig. 1 Optimized structure and spin density distribution of (a, c) PAG, and (b, d) Co-PAG, respectively. The isosurface value is kept around 0.048 e Å−3. The pink and green color signifies positive and negative spin density, respectively. Simulated STM images (Vbias = + 0.2 V) of (e) PAG and (f) Co-PAG based on the optimized structure shown in Fig. 1 (a, b), respectively. The unit cell is highlighted with red dotted lines. The band structures and density of states analysis of (i) PAG and (j) Co-PAG, respectively. The HOMO/LUMO orbitals analysis of (g, k) PAG and (h, l) Co-PAG with isosurface of 0.009 e Å−3. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 | Top and side views of (a, d) H2 adsorption, (b, e) CO2 adsorption, and (c, f) H2 CO2 adsorption on CoPAG, respectively. The bond distances are measured in Å. Only a part of Co-PAG is shown in Fig. 2. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 | Top and side views of charge density difference of (a, c) H2/Co-PAG and (b, d) CO2/Co-PAG with the isosurface of 0.009 e Å −3. The pink and green color signifies electron loss and accumulation, respectively. The ELF analysis of (e) H2/Co-PAG and (f) CO2/Co-PAG, respectively. Only a part of Co-PAG is shown in Fig. 3. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 | The schematic reaction pathway of CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid on Co-PAG with the corresponding structure along the reaction path. TS1 and TS2 denote transition states along the reaction path. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 | Electrochemical reduction reaction pathway of CO2 to (a) formic acid (b) CO and (c) HER at zero potential on PAG and Co-PAG materials. The corresponding structure along the reaction path of (d) HCOOH, (e) CO, and (f) the schematic HER and CO2RR reaction process on Co-PAG materials. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 | Charge density difference plot of CO2RR intermediated step of (a, b) COOH*, HCOOH*on Co-PAG and (c, d) COOH*, HCOOH*on PAG, respectively. Quantum Functional Materials and Devices, Southern University of Science and Technology, Shenzhen 518055, China ⁎ Corresponding author. In this work, we report novel single-layered porous aza-fused π-conjugated graphene-analogous 2D materials (PAG) with well-organized nanopores and consistently allocated nitrogen atoms as supporting specie to coordinate cobalt (Co) atom through nitrogen inside (Co-PAG), for CO2 conversion to formic-acid by hydrogenation and electrochemical approaches. Because of the synergetic effect of structural characteristics and Co-coordination, the band gap of Co-PAG is reduced to 0.7 eV, while that of PAG is 1.79 eV. The molecular dynamic (MD) simulations uncover the stability of PAG/Co-PAG. From reaction pathway analysis, it is concluded that Co-PAG can effectively hydrogenate CO2 to formic acid. The highest barrier is 0.78 eV, which is feasible for experiments to carry out this reaction at elevated temperatures. Furthermore, the overpotential requirement for PAG material in CO2 electroreduction (CO2RR) to formic-acid is 0.46 V which is significantly larger than that for Co-PAG (0.18 V). Both PAG and Co-PAG surfaces retain higher selectivity for formic acid than that of carbon mono oxides and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and cobalt coordination in PAG support makes the formic-acid reaction path significantly energy favorable. These results confirm that PAG can be possible catalyst support and that Co-coordination in PAG material makes the formic-acid reaction path significantly more energy favorable. Graphical abstract Cobalt coordinated single-layered porous aza-fused π-conjugated graphene analogous 2D material a stable and active electrocatalyst for CO2 reduction reaction Image, graphical abstract Keywords Porous graphene-analogous 2D material Single-atom catalyst CO2 hydrogenation CO2RR DFT 1 Introduction Recently, there has been an increase interest in solving energy challenges, and it is critical to develop new sources of sustainable energy. Photocatalysis and electrocatalysis are the important parts of electrochemical processes to encounter these challenges [1–9]. Moreover, the over-consumption of fossil fuels has caused excessive CO2 emissions over the past two centuries, leading to critical ecological changes, for instance, global warming, water level rise in the sea, and deforestation [10,11]. To decrease our dependence on fossil fuel the ideal solution is to renovate and utilize CO2 into renewable energy [12–14]. This strategy could restrain the greenhouse effect and resolve energy deficit problems [11]. CO2 could be converted into formic acid, methanol, methane, and other imperative chemical compounds through hydrogenation, photocatalytic, and electrocatalytic processes [6,11, 15-19]. However, the formation of formic acid from CO2 by electrochemical and hydrogenation approaches is among the most favorable methods because of their excellent performance and suitability for industrial applications. Via CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR), formic acid is obtained, which is a promising product since its extensive usage as the precursor material in textile, pharmaceutical, and leather whipping industries [20,21]. Besides that, formic acid is a promising hydrogen storing material [22]. At room temperature, it can be disintegrated catalytically into CO2 and H2 [23] and used as a direct fuel, without pretreatment process [24]. The difficulty in producing formic acid effectively relates to its CO2 activation due to its thermal stability [25]. Several transition metals have been extensively researched as CO2RR catalysts, with different selectivities toward the reduction products [26–29]. Moreover, metal-based heterogeneous catalysts often show significant CO2 to formic acid activity at low overpotentials [26,30,31]. However, numerous shortcomings are unavoidable. To begin with the disadvantages of the metal-based heterogeneous catalytic system are surface heterogeneity and internal diffusion [32]; Secondly, it is influenced by interphase diffusion, which results in inadequate catalytic activity [33]; Thirdly, the majority of metal atoms in heterogeneous catalysts are in the bulk phase, and only a few metal atoms on the surface exhibit catalytic activity, resulting in a poor metal atom usage rate [34]. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) could resolve these issues and gain extraordinary stability, better catalytic performance, and astonishing atomic productivity. Nonetheless, SACs typically combine and form a cluster on the host material because of the unique surface-free energy. A conceivable routine to bypass the accumulation issue of SACs could be the use of apposite host material throughout the synthesis and reaction process because good support can behave as a steady attachment or coordination site for SACs and tune their catalytic performance [1, 35-41]. Therefore, research on supporting materials gains considerable interest in the scientific community. Among the numerous support materials, graphene, a kind of carbon-rich material, is highly promising for SACs [41,42]. But pure graphene is a zero-gap material [43,44], which is a distinct drawback and limits its industrial application. To cover the requirements of different research areas, for instance, catalysis, energy storage, and chemical conversion, graphene's properties need to be tuned by doping or defects because these can change the crystallinity and the electronic structures of graphene and present active sites and band gap [40, 45-52]. Furthermore, improvements can be made by considering the porous graphene functionalized with heteroatoms, including N, B, etc. [52–55]. In this case, the N atom possesses a lone pair of electrons, which can activate reactions or can act as a Lewis base, and therefore will play a central role in a catalytic reaction. Inspired by doping strategy and structural modification on graphene, it is expected that it's analogous can be a possible support material. Several graphene-analogous porous materials with exceptional properties such as diverse crystallinity, low density, thermal and chemical stability have been developed, broadening their application in areas such as energy storage and electro-catalysis [52, 56-58]. Moreover, 2D porous organic networks, 2D metals- and covalent-organic framework with porous structure and doped heteroatoms have been studied extensively for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and CO2RR [59–63], but unfortunately, because of poor graphitic degree, which is liable for unfavorable ion-electron transport [64]. On the other hand, mostly electrocatalysts reported for CO2RR are based on transition metal oxides reinforced by carbon materials to enable electron transfer. Despite the fact that metal-based electrocatalysts have recently grown in popularity, the use of well-defined nitrogenated two-dimensional material has never been studied, and no truly single atoms hosted in well-defined nitrogenated two-dimensional material based CO2RR electrocatalyst has been reported to date. Hence, by using theoretical calculations based on density functional theory (DFT), we design new 2D materials with highly ordered nanopores and evenly distributed nitrogen atoms called porous aza-fused π-conjugated graphene analogous 2D materials (PAG). The PAG materials work as a support to coordinate cobalt (Co) atoms through nitrogen inside (Co-PAG) for CO2 conversion to formic acid by hydrogenation and electrochemical approaches. For the last two decades, DFT tools have been proven to be an efficient method for exploring explore new materials. DFT can also provide further benefits to understand the mechanistic insight of catalytic processes, the structures of reactants and the transition states along the reaction pathways, and the role of catalyst supports, which is hard to obtain from experiments alone. Using this method, we further explored the structural, electronic, and catalytic properties of PAG and Co-PAG support. A comprehensive description of the minimum energy path is illustrated, which sheds light on the mechanism. The current study aims to give the idea of new 2D material support for single-atom beyond Co and enhance the doping strategies to broaden the applications of graphene and its analogous 2D materials. Furthermore, both PAG and Co-PAG have a narrow band gap of 1.79 and 0.7 eV, respectively, and thus have enormous potential in areas other than catalysis, such as semiconductors, batteries, and energy storage devices [54, 65-67]. 2 Computational setup The present study has been performed by using DFT with generalized gradient approximation (GGA) and the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [68] functional for the exchange-correlation potentials that have been accomplished through the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [69–71]. In order to optimize the structure, a 5 × 5 × 1 k-point and a 450 eV energy cutoff have been applied. Furthermore, to calculate the band gap, we used HSE06 functional and the k-point was set to 8 × 8 × 1. The DFT-D3 correction model of Grimme was used in DFT calculations [72] to interpret the dispersive intermolecular interactions and van der Waals interaction corrections that are expected to occur due to CO2 and PAG surface interaction. The main advantage of DFT-D3 is its computational efficiency and durability across the periodic table, which makes this technique particularly useful for large-scale systems. For the surface configuration, Tersoff-Hamann approximation was used to mimic scanning tunneling microscope (STM) images, in which the current is proportional to the local density of state (LDOS) of the surface at a given tip position integrated from the Fermi level (EF) to applied voltage bias (Ef +eVbias) [73]. Meanwhile, the adsorption energy (Eads) can be calculated using the equation below: (1) E ads = E support + adsorbate − ( E adsorbate + E support ) where Esupport+adsorbate, Esupport, and Eadsorbate are the total energies of support materials (PAG/Co-PAG) with adsorbate, the isolated PAG/Co-PAG, and the free, H2, CO2, and H2 CO2, respectively. The PAG was modeled via a periodic unit cell containing 30 atoms (24 carbon and 6 nitrogen atoms). The PAG unit cell is hexagonal with unit-cell parameters a = b = 13.86, c = 14.94 Å and α = β = 90°; γ = 60° in reciprocal space and the periodic condition is employed along the a and b directions. To examine all possible active sites for adsorbates, we started from this unit cell and constructed 2 × 2 supercell of PAG containing 120 atoms (96 carbon and 24 nitrogen atoms) and added the vacuum space of 15 Å along c direction to avoid self interactions. The computational cost of this supercell is reasonable to study the structural, electronic and catalytic properties of PAG materials at efficient accuracy. The total energy was converged to an accuracy of 1 × 10−5 eV to obtain accurate forces, and a force tolerance of −0.02 eV/Å was applied in the structure optimization. The molecular dynamic simulations with canonical (NVT) ensemble Nose thermostat [74] methods were employed to study the thermodynamic stability of PAG/Co-PAG at 300 K, 500 K, 800 K, and 1000 K, respectively, with a time step of 1 fs for 5 ps. The minimum energy path for CO2 hydrogenation reaction has been calculated using the climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method [75]. In addition, the amount of charge transfer was calculated by the Bader charge technique [76,77]. Similarly, the CO2 electroreduction reaction (CO2RR) to HCOOH and CO proceeds via a two-electron transfer mechanism and comprises two proton-electron coupled elementary steps: CO2RR to HCOOH: (2) * + C O 2 ( g ) + 2 ( H + + e − ) → H C O O * + H + + e − (3) H C O O * + H + + e − → H C O O H * (4) H C O O H * → H C O O H ( l ) + * CO2RR to CO: (5) * + C O 2 ( g ) + 2 ( H + + e − ) → * C O O H + H + + e − (6) * C O O H + H + + e − → * C O + H 2 O ( l ) (7) * CO + C O ( g ) + * Hydrogen: (8) H + + e − + * → H * (9) H * → 1 ( H 2 ) 2 + * where ∗ signifies the active site of catalysts, (g) indicated gas phase (l) indicated liquid phase, respectively, and HCOOH*, HCOO*, *CO, *COOH, and H* are the adsorbed intermediates. The Gibbs free energy for reactants, intermediate, and the resulting product is defined as, (10) G = E DFT + E ZPE − TS where E D F T , E Z P E , and T S represent zero-point energy, electronic energy, and room temperature entropy (i.e., T = 298.15 K). The Gibbs free energy was determined by computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model for the reaction step that involves coupled proton-electron, such that the free energy of electron-proton pairs (e −+ H+ ) was calculated as a function of applied potential (U) relative to a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE), i.e., μ(H +) + μ(e −) = 1 2 μ(H2) – eU [78]. The adsorption free energies of HCOO*, HCOOH*, *COOH, *CO and H* at a given potential U R H E can be calculated as: (11) Δ G 1 ( H C O O * ) = ( H C O O H * ) − G ( * ) − G ( C O 2 ( g ) ) − 1 G ( H 2 ) 2 − e U R H E (12) Δ G 2 ( H C O O H * ) = ( H C O O H * ) − ( H C O O ) − 1 G ( H 2 ) 2 − e U R H E (13) Δ G 3 ( C O O H * ) = G ( C O O H * ) − G ( * ) − G ( C O 2 ( g ) ) − 1 G ( H 2 ) 2 − e U R H E (14) Δ G 4 ( * C O ) = G ( * C O ) − G ( C O O H * ) + G ( H 2 O ( l ) ) − 1 G ( H 2 ) 2 − e U R H E (15) Δ G 5 ( H * ) = G ( H * ) − G ( * ) − 1 G ( H 2 ) 2 − e U R H E 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Geometrical structure and the electronic properties of PAG and Co-PAG To evaluate whether a material can be a good catalyst support or not, its stability and electronic properties need to be considered. Therefore, we first inspect the atomic structures of PAG and Co-PAG materials, as indicated in Fig. 1 (a, b), respectively. As the unit cell of graphene comprises two carbon atoms, and the unit-cell of PAG can be built by replacing each of the double bonds in graphene with three fused-benzenes to form a graphene analogous honeycomb structure, which is highly nitrogenated (20%). After optimization, the optimized lattice parameter of PAG is 13.85 Å while its pore diameter is 10 Å which is within the range of the previous experimentally measured pore size of COF materials (9–16.5 Å) [79]. When Co is introduced, the optimized lattice parameter (12.03 Å) and pore diameter (6.3 Å) both become smaller than PAG. Moreover, the spin density around the active site increases with cobalt coordination, as shown in Fig. 1 (c, d), resulting in good catalytic activity around Co sites. The atomic structure is also examined by simulated scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) (Fig. 1e, f). The STM images revealed the hexagonal structure of PAG and Co-PAG materials where Co is clearly shown to be coordinated through two nitrogens. Furthermore, the structural stability of PAG and Co-PAG were confirmed by MD-simulations at temperatures ranging (300–1000 K), with a time step of 1 fs for 5 ps. It is worth noting that for 300, 500, and 800 K, the PAG and Co-PAG preserve their morphology. however; at 1000 K, the morphology is a little distorted, while Co retains its original position (Figure S1). These results revealed that both PAG and Co-PAG materials persist its stability and are therefore feasible for high-temperature experimental application. Further, the electronic structure of the PAG and Co-PAG materials was investigated using the HSE06 method. The band gap and density of states (PDOS) calculations indicate that PAG and Co-PAG are semiconductor materials with band gaps of 1.79 and 0.70 eV, respectively, as shown in Fig. 1(i, j). The decrease of band gap with Co-coordinating reveals a strong interaction between Co and PAG material which would be very beneficial for catalytic applications. The orbitals analysis shown in Fig. 1(g, k) reveals that the HOMO/LUMO of PAG is consistently dispersed and symmetrized. In contrast, with Co-coordination, the symmetric HOMO/LUMO orbitals of PAG are disrupted and cause a substantial increment of the spin density around Co atoms (Fig. 1h, l). Consequently, the Co site maybe active towards reactants' adsorption during CO2 hydrogenation and reduction and will subsequently increase the reactivity. 3.2 Adsorption of reactants (CO2, H2, and H2 CO2) on PAG and Co-PAG The interaction of reactants (H2, CO2, and H2 CO2) with supporting materials always plays a central role in a chemical reaction. Thus, it is essential to understand how the reactants adsorb on the support. As shown in Figure S2, H2 is adsorbed in a dissociated form on the surface of nitrogen in PAG material. Whereas CO2 is adsorbed very weakly on PAG support and the adsorption energy of −0.18 eV. On the contrary, H2 and CO2 are adsorbed strongly on Co-PAG materials. Therefore, we only consider Co-PAG material for further hydrogenation reaction catalytic reactions. The optimized structures of CO2, H2, and co-adsorbed H2 CO2 on Co-PAG support are shown in Fig. 2 . It can be seen that in adsorbed CO2 the angel between O=C=O bond is tilted from 180˚ to 145.2˚, and each O=C bond distance enlarges to 1.28 Å compared with the gas phase which is 1.18 Å. Similarly, the H–H bond distance of the adsorbed H2 is significantly elongated (0.88 ˚A) compared with that of the isolated H2 molecule with a value of 0.74 Å. The elongation in the H−H and CO bonds shows that the adsorbed CO2 and H2 are activated by Co sites in Co-PAG support. The adsorption energy values and charge on reactants are listed in Table 1 . The reactants H2 and CO2 adsorb readily on a Co site in Co-PAG support. However, H2 has considerably larger adsorption energy (−0.99 eV) than CO2 (−0.59 eV), suggesting that the hydrogenation reaction will be started with H2 adsorption. In co-adsorption of H2 and CO2 molecules shown in Fig. 2 (c, f), H2 directly binds with Co, and CO2 is physisorbed with co-adsorption energy is −1.02 eV which is listed in Table 1. Moreover, both H2 and CO2 gain charge from Co as indicated in Table 1, which is consistent with the prior report [80]. The charge transfer is further confirmed in the polts of charge density difference (Fig. 3 a-d). The electron localization function (ELF) in Fig. 3e shows that highly localized electrons are around Co and H2 and form a covalent bond. In contrast, the overlapping of electrons between Co and CO2 is weaker than Co-H2, as shown in Fig. 3f. 3.3 Reaction mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid over Co-PAG Due to the excellent adsorption capacity of H2 and CO2 on Co-PAG support, we further uncover the reaction mechanisms of CO2 hydrogenation as depicted in Fig. 4 . The first step of the reaction is the adsorption of H2 because H2 has a stronger adsorption energy than CO2. This step is exothermic with an energy decrease of 0.99 eV, indicated as step IS in Fig. 4. In the second step, H2 is dissociated, and the H–H bond is elongated on the surface of Co from 0.88 to 2.03 Å in TS1, where one of the H atoms binds with the Co atom in Co-PAG and the other H atom tends to approach the carbon atom of the Co-PAG support. An energy barrier of 0.78 eV is needed at TS1 to form an intermediate MS1, wherein the HH bond is completely broken. In the next step, CO2 attacks on dissociated H atoms, and the reaction passes through TS2 via surmounting an energy barrier of 0.07 eV. In TS2, the H on the surface of Co is discarded from the Co surface and makes a bond with CO2, which is adsorbed on Co site with the O atom attached at the Co site. In the second intermediate MS2, the distance between Co and O decreased to 1.93 Å, while the CH bond distance is 1.13 Å. Subsequently, the reaction passes through TS3 with an energy barrier of 0.49 eV, and the bond between carbon in Co-PAG and H atom breaks, and the H atom binds to the O atom of adsorbed CO2 and forms formic acid (HCOOH). In the last step, formic is released from the support. From the thermodynamics point of view, the step of IS1→TS1→MS1 requires the highest energy barrier, with a value of only 0.78 eV. 3.4 CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) to formic-acid and CO over PAG and Co-PAG Then, we turn to study electrochemical CO2RR to formic-acid (HCOOH). Because it involves the adsorption of CO2 with a couple of electron-proton in the form of carboxyl species, both PAG and Co-PAG materials are considered, and the results are summarized in Table S1. The free-energy reaction pathway at 0 V vs. RHE, along with optimized adsorbed configurations of reactants, intermediates, and the products on PAG and Co-PAG surfaces, are displayed in Fig. 5 . CO2 is activated on the surface of nitrogen and Co with the transfer of proton/electron pair, which makes the construction of bound carboxylate intermediate (*COOH) on N and Co sites via a carbon atom or the formation of the bound formate intermediate (HCOO*) on N and Co site via two oxygen atoms. The HCOO* and *COOH are considered to be the intermediate step for the constructions of both HCOOH and CO [21,81]. In CO2RR to HCOOH pathway, the Gibbs free energies (ΔG) required for the formation of HCOO* and HCOOH* are 0.46 and 0.17 eV, correspondingly, on PAG surfaces (Fig. 5a). Understandably, CO2 is a chemically stable molecule having electrophilic carbon at the center and possesses a linear molecular geometry. Hence, the first electron transfer to form the HCOO* intermediate needs a high overpotential of 0.46 V vs. RHE at U = 0 V. However, with Co-coordination, the respective ΔG for HCOO* and HCOOH* significantly reduce to 0.18 and 0.12 eV, respectively (Fig. 5a), and a low overpotential of 0.18 V is required to carry on this reaction. Therefore, the protonation of CO2 to HCOO* governs the overpotential. Moreover, the final product HCOOH in CO2RR is controlled by intermediated step (HCOO*), and a good catalyst stabilized HCOO* strongly than HCOOH*. Our calculation reveals that both PAG and Co-PAG adsorb COOH* compared to HCOOH*. However, Co-PAG stabilizes COOH* strongly than PAG. The strong interaction is further exposed from Bader charge analysis and a large amount of charge (0.72 e) transfer from Co-PAG to COOH* surface, which leads to the negative charge COOH* as confirmed by the charge density difference plot shown in Fig. 6 a. On the contrary, a lower amount of charge (0.35 |e|) transfer between COOH* and PAG materials are consistent with the charge density difference plot (Fig. 6c). These results confirm that Co-coordination in PAG support makes the HCOOH reaction path significantly energy favorable. Moreover, for CO2RR to CO pathway, the Gibbs free energies required to form *COOH are 0.85 and 0.49 eV on PAG and Co-PAG, respectively (Fig. 5b). These results confirm that Co-coordination in PAG material makes the formic-acid reaction path significantly energy favorable. The comparison of the different catalysts with the current study is despit in Table S2, indicating that Co-PAG's performance is comparable or even better than the previous reports. Similarly, we examined ΔG for the HER on PAG and Co-PAG materials (Fig. 5c). Our calculation revealed that the overpotential required for HER in PAG is 1.18 and for Co-PAG is 0.52 V (Fig. 5c), which indicates that HER is suppressed during CO2RR to HCOOH. Our theoretical findings revealed that both PAG and Co-PAG surfaces have higher HCOOH selectivity than CO and HER and that cobalt coordination in PAG support makes the HCOOH reaction more energy favorable. 4 Conclusion In this work, for the first time, the porous aza-fused π-conjugated graphene analogous 2D materials (PAG) and Co-coordinated PAG (Co-PAG) were carefully explored using DFT calculations mainly focusing on their structural, electronic, and catalytic properties. The structure is crystalline with distinct nanopores and extremely well-ordered N atoms covalently bonded to a carbonic framework. The structure stability is outstanding for both PAG and Co-PAG even at 1000 K. Because of the synergetic effect of structural characteristics and Co-coordination, the band gap of Co-PAG is reduced to 0.7 eV, while that of PAG is 1.79 eV. Moreover, the spin density around the active site increases with cobalt coordination, resulting in good catalytic activity around Co sites. H2 and CO2 readily adsorb on Co-PAG. However, H2 adsorbs more strongly than CO2, which implies that the hydrogenation reaction will be started with the adsorption of H2. Moreover, from the reaction pathways analysis for the CO2 hydrogenation to formic-acid, it is concluded that Co-PAG can effectively hydrogenate CO2 to formic acid. The highest barrier along the complete reaction path is 0.78 eV which is feasible for the experiment to carry out this reaction at an elevated temperature. On the other hand, in the process of CO2RR to formic-acid, the overpotential required for PAG material is 0.46 V vs. RHE at U = 0 V, which is significantly larger than for Co-PAG (0.18 V). Moreover, in the CO2RR to CO pathway, the overpotential requires for PAG material is 0.85 V vs. RHE at U = 0 V, which is significantly larger than for Co-PAG (0.49 V). While, for HER, the overpotential is 1.18 and 0.52 V for PAG and Co-PAG, respectively. Therefore, the HCOOH reaction scheme is more energy-favorable compared to CO and HER. These results confirm that Co-coordination in PAG material makes the formic-acid reaction path significantly more energy favorable. The present study successfully proposes a new 2D material support for single-atom beyond Co and enhances the doping strategies to broaden the applications of graphene analogous 2D materials. coredata.dc:description: In this work, we report novel single-layered porous aza-fused π-conjugated graphene-analogous 2D materials (PAG) with well-organized nanopores and consistently allocated nitrogen atoms as supporting specie to coordinate cobalt (Co) atom through nitrogen inside (Co-PAG), for CO2 conversion to formic-acid by hydrogenation and electrochemical approaches. Because of the synergetic effect of structural characteristics and Co-coordination, the band gap of Co-PAG is reduced to 0.7 eV, while that of PAG is 1.79 eV. The molecular dynamic (MD) simulations uncover the stability of PAG/Co-PAG. From reaction pathway analysis, it is concluded that Co-PAG can effectively hydrogenate CO2 to formic acid. The highest barrier is 0.78 eV, which is feasible for experiments to carry out this reaction at elevated temperatures. Furthermore, the overpotential requirement for PAG material in CO2 electroreduction (CO2RR) to formic-acid is 0.46 V which is significantly larger than that for Co-PAG (0.18 V). Both PAG and Co-PAG surfaces retain higher selectivity for formic acid than that of carbon mono oxides and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and cobalt coordination in PAG support makes the formic-acid reaction path significantly energy favorable. These results confirm that PAG can be possible catalyst support and that Co-coordination in PAG material makes the formic-acid reaction path significantly more energy favorable.
coredata.dc:title: Porous aza-doped graphene-analogous 2D material a unique catalyst for CO2 conversion to formic-acid by hydrogenation and electroreduction approaches
